aws::graph::propositions: # CT Scanning of Rudder Gust Lock Actuator
A rudder gust lock actuator was subjected to x-ray computed tomography scanning to document its internal condition.
The scanning was conducted from December 24, 2014 to March 23, 2015.
The scanning was supervised by a lead aerospace engineer assigned to the NTSB's Aviation Engineering Division.
The NTSB's Aviation Engineering Division is located at NTSB Headquarters in Washington, D.C.
The scans were performed by Varian Medical Systems, Inc.
Varian Medical Systems, Inc. was formerly known as Bio-Imaging Research, Inc. (BIR).
Varian Medical Systems used a combination of the Varian Actis 500/225 microfocus CT system and the Actis 500/450 standard focus CT system.
For the CT scans, the component was loaded into the imaging unit.
The component was placed on a turntable.
The component was rotated in front of the x-ray source.
X-rays were captured by a detector after they went through the part.
The x-ray source produced a fan beam of x-rays.
The portion of the part imaged was adjusted slightly after each scan was completed.
The adjustments continued until the entire assembly was scanned.
The x-ray energy levels were recorded at several thousand different points during each rotation.
The recorded information was converted into slice images using a reconstruction algorithm.
The actuator was scanned using a total of 6,421 slices.
The total size of the combined data sets was 50.26 Gb.
The actuator was scanned multiple times with different scanning protocols.
The actuator was scanned using both the microfocus imaging system and the standard focus imaging systems.
The microfocus scans provided the best possible spatial resolution.
Microfocus imaging was constrained to a lower power level.
The lower power level resulted in streaking artifacts within the images.
The standard focus scans used a higher power level.
The standard focus scans had a lower spatial resolution than microfocus scans.
The higher power levels eliminated the streak artifacts.
The standard focus scans had an inherently higher contrast resolution.
Target CT imaging using the microfocus system was used for selected areas.
Target CT imaging was used to get the highest possible resolution.
The entire part scans were re-reconstructed using different reconstruction parameters.
The limit switch scans were re-reconstructed using different reconstruction parameters.
The re-reconstruction was an effort to highlight the low density components within the scans.

text:
# Tests and Research

## Computed Tomography (CT Scanning)

Under the supervision of a lead aerospace engineer assigned to the NTSB's Aviation Engineering Division, located at NTSB Headquarters, Washington, D.C., the rudder gust lock actuator was subjected to x-ray computed tomography (CT) scanning to document its internal condition. The scanning was conducted from December 24, 2014 to March 23, 2015. The scans were performed by Varian Medical Systems, Inc. (formerly Bio-Imaging Research, Inc. (BIR) using a combination of the Varian Actis 500/225 microfocus CT system and the Actis 500/450 standard focus CT system.

For the CT scans, the component was loaded into the imaging unit and placed on a turntable. It was then rotated in front of the x-ray source, and the x-rays were captured by a detector after they went through the part. The x-ray source produced a fan beam of x-rays, and the portion of the part imaged was adjusted slightly after each scan was completed until the entire assembly was scanned. The x-ray energy levels captured by the detector were recorded at several thousand different points during each rotation. This information was then converted into slice images using a reconstruction algorithm.

The actuator was scanned using a total of 6,421 slices. The total size of the combined data sets was 50.26 Gb. The actuator was scanned multiple times with different scanning protocols using both the microfocus imaging system and the standard focus imaging systems. The microfocus scans provided the best possible spatial resolution, but this type of imaging was constrained to a lower power level that resulted in streaking artifacts within the images. The standard focus scans used a higher power level (with a lower spatial resolution), but these higher power levels eliminated the streak artifacts, and had an inherently higher contrast resolution. Target CT imaging using the microfocus system was used for selected areas to get the highest possible resolution. In addition, the entire part scans and the limit switch scans were re-reconstructed using different reconstruction parameters in an effort to highlight the low density components within the scans.
